person_609.name: Thales
person_609.description: Ancient Greek pre-Socratic philosopher from Miletus in Ionia, Asia Minor.

person_445.name: Pythagoras
person_445.description: Pythagoras of Samos was an ancient Ionian Greek philosopher, polymath, and the eponymous founder of Pythagoreanism. Believed in the primacy of number.

person_035.name: Homer
person_035.description: Homer was a Greek poet who is believed to have written the epic poems, the Iliad and the Odyssey.

person_1039.name: DiogenesLaërtius
person_1039.description: a biographer of the Greek philosophers

person_1040.name: Josephus
person_1040.description: a Roman–Jewish historian and military leader

person_951.name: JesusChrist
person_951.description: The central figure of Christianity; a first-century Jewish preacher and religious leader.

person_602.name: Plutarch
person_602.description: Greek writer most famous for his parallel lives of Greek and Roman statesmen and military leaders.

person_869.name: Jean-Baptiste Louis Roméde Lisle
person_869.description: A French mineralogist, considered one of the creators of modern crystallography

person_307.name: René JustHaüy
person_307.description: French priest, crystallographer and mineralogist who wrote the five volume Traité de minéralogie (1801). ForMemRSL.

person_1043.name: LucanusOcellus
person_1043.description: allegedly a Pythagorean philosopher, born in Lucania in Magna Graecia

person_865.name: Heraclitus
person_865.description: An ancient Greek pre-Socratic philosopher from the city of Ephesus, which was then part of the Persian Empire.

person_905.name: Parmenides
person_905.description: a pre-Socratic Greek philosopher from Elea in Magna Graecia.

person_903.name: Empedocles
person_903.description: Ancient Greek philosopher whose philosophy is best known for originating the cosmogonic theory of the four classical elements.

person_1044.name: Zeno
person_1044.description: of Elea, a pre-Socratic Greek philosopher

person_906.name: Leucippus
person_906.description: a pre-Socratic Greek philosopher. He is traditionally credited as the founder of atomism, which he developed with his student Democritus. Leucippus divided the world into two entities: atoms, indivisible particles that make up all things, and the void, the nothingness that exists between the atoms.

person_140.name: Socrates
person_140.description: Greek philosopher whose work survives mostly through the writings of his pupil Plato. Executed by the democratic Athenian state for sedition.

person_085.name: Plato
person_085.description: A pupil of Socrates, much of Plato's large corpus of surviving philosophical texts are written in the form of Socratic dialogues. He espoused a philosophical idealism including the primacy of mathematics and an anti-democratic political philosophy because of the execution of Socrates. Plato's writings have been, and are, so influential that all subsequent philosophy has been described as footnotes to Plato.

person_907.name: Aristophanes
person_907.description: a comic playwright or comedy-writer of ancient Athens and a poet of Old Attic Comedy.

person_138.name: Aristotle
person_138.description: A pupil of Plato's whose philosophical idealism he came to reject, arguing instead for the primacy of observations of natural phenomena. He thus established the divide between theory and experiment in science that can still be detected today. Aristotle's writings became the main way the natural world was understood from the Middle Ages to the seventeenth century, especially in the universities.

person_692.name: ThomasAquinas
person_692.description: Italian Dominican friar and priest, an influential philosopher and theologian, and a jurist in the tradition of scholasticism from the county of Aquino in the Kingdom of Sicily. Thomas was a prominent proponent of natural theology and the father of a school of thought known as Thomism.

person_810.name: Alexander III
person_810.description: The Great, King of Macedon, from which he conquered much of the world known in Greek antiquity.

person_277.name: Theophrastus
person_277.description: A Greek philosopher and the successor to Aristotle in the Peripatetic school.

person_723.name: Epicurus
person_723.description: Ancient Greek philosopher, an atomist and materialist, following in the steps of Democritus and founder of Epicureanism.

person_182.name: Democritus
person_182.description: Pre-Socratic Greek philosopher who proposed a form of atomism.

person_508.name: Lucretius
person_508.description: Roman poet and philosopher. His only known work is the materialist philosophical poem De rerum natura.

person_1045.name: Phaedrus
person_1045.description: an ancient Athenian aristocrat associated with the inner-circle of the philosopher Socrates

person_877.name: Marcus TuilliusCicero
person_877.description: a Roman statesman, lawyer, scholar, philosopher, writer and Academic skeptic

person_185.name: Pliny
person_185.description: The Elder. Roman army officer and author who wrote an encyclopedic Natural History. Died in the aftermath of the eruption of Vesuvius.

person_132.name: Martin afPontin
person_132.description: Swedish court physician. Worked with Berzelius on following up Davy's work in electro-chemistry.

place_1120.name: Samos
place_1120.description: A Greek island in the eastern Aegean Sea, separated from Turkey by the mile-wide Mycale Strait. It was the birthplace of mathematician Pythagoras and philosopher Epicurus.

place_1119.name: Crotone
place_1119.description: a port city in Calabria, southern Italy. Founded c. 710 BC as the Achaean colony of Kroton it became a great Greek city, home of the renowned mathematician-philosopher Pythagoras.

place_184.name: Mount Etna
place_184.description: Mount Etna, or simply Etna, is an active stratovolcano on the east coast of Sicily, Italy.

place_1133.name: Abdera
place_1133.description: a municipality in the Xanthi regional unit of Thrace, Greece. In classical antiquity, it was a major Greek polis on the Thracian coast.

place_208.name: Athens
place_208.description: Athens is the capital city of Greece.

place_538.name: Liguria
place_538.description: Liguria is a region of north west Italy. Its capital is Genoa.

place_085.name: Derbyshire
place_085.description: Derbyshire is a county in the East Midlands and includes part of the Peak District.

place_710.name: Miseno
place_710.description: A port near Naples, Italy, to the north of the Gulf of Naples.

otherwork_314.name: On the Nature of the Gods
otherwork_314.author: Cicero
